Issues.Title: Content in default slot causes component to re-render when the parent re-renders
Issues.Body: ### Version 2.5.16 ### Reproduction link [https://codepen.io/JosephSilber/pen/KeWjzr](https://codepen.io/JosephSilber/pen/KeWjzr) ### Description Passing content in a slot causes the component to re-render when the parent re-renders, even if the component's data hasn't changed. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a simple component that shows the amount of times it's been rendered: ```js Vue.component('times-rendered', { created() { this.timesRendered = 0 }, render(h) { return h('div', `Times rendered: ${++this.timesRendered}`) } }); ``` 2. Use this component twice. Once with content in the default slot, once without. After the component is mounted, trigger any update to its data: ```html ``` ### What is expected? I would expect each instance of the component to only render once. ### What is actually happening? The component with content in the slot renders twice. --- I'm not actually sure whether this is a bug or a feature request. Maybe this is expected behavior currently. If it is, then I guess this would be better classified as a feature request.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Content in default slot causes component to re-render when the parent re-renders" (#8342)

有什么好的方案吗？vue框架中适合使用事件代理吗？

Issues.Title: Nested component's v-model doesn't trigger its updated lifecycle method when a parent dynamic component is updated by provide/inject
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/linnea/zmkt7ajy/15/](https://jsfiddle.net/linnea/zmkt7ajy/15/)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Click on the working checkbox. The v-model value updates and the "updated" lifecycle event fires a console log.
2. Click on the "busted" checkbox, which is the same markup as the working checkbox, but wrapped within a div inside the DynamicWrap component. 

Notice that the checkbox appears checked, but the v-model doesn't update and the "updated" lifecycle event of the checkbox never fires.


### What is expected?
The second checkbox's v-model updates correctly

### What is actually happening?
No updated lifecycle event fires, the v-model is not updated.

---
What's happening:
The DynamicWrapper is rerendered after mount when the UnwrappedCheckbox is created inside of its default slot. UnwrappedCheckbox uses provide/inject to update the DynamicWrap component to wrap it with a 'div' instead of a 'label' element. This clones the content inside, but once the Checkbox is nested a layer deeper, it stops behaving as expected.

Sorry for the monster title and complex replication, let me know if there's anything more I can do to clarify. For context, the purpose of this DynamicWrapper is to act as a type of "FormItem" component. It wraps any element placed inside of the component (In this case a Checkbox) with a label element unless it's something like a Checkbox or Radio. We have our own Checkbox and Radio, that we'd like to tell the FormItem to unwrap the label if a Checkbox is placed inside it.

I've also tested in the beta prerelease and the issue remains.

Possible related previous issues:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6372
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6915

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Nested component's v-model doesn't trigger its updated lifecycle method when a parent dynamic component is updated by provide/inject" (#8337)

Issues.Title: Fix "#" placed incorrectly when query string is present on load (#2125)
Issues.Body:
When navigating to a URL with a query string like `myapp.com?foo=bar` in hash mode, the hash is currently placed after the query string `myapp.com?foo=bar#/`

This fix correctly parses URLs with query strings so that the above URL will be `myapp.com/#/?foo=bar` after loading.

Issues.Title: Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112](https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112)

### Steps to reproduce
Look at the codepen snippet.

It contains **isObjectEqual(a, b)** implementation from *vue-router/src/util/route.js* and an example of it's unexpected behaviour.

Console output represents the issue.

### What is expected?
In the codepen **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is used on two objects: 

```a: { foo: true, bar: undefined } ```

```b: { foo: true, baz: 'qux' } ```

What is expected: 
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is expected to return false since **Object b** has 'baz' property with 'qux' value and **Object a**  doesn't have such property at all.

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** is expected to return false for the same reason.

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result should be equal to **isObjectEqual (b, a)** result.

### What is actually happening?
What is happening:
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** returns true (unexpected).

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** returns false (expected).  

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result is not equal to **isObjectEqual(b, a)** result  (unexpected).

Same thing will happen with any **Object a** and **Object b** if conditions below are met:

- **Object a** and **Object b** have the same amount of properties.

- **Object b** must have same properties with same values that are present in **Object a** with values different from undefined.


---
Issue with **isObjectEqual** causes issues with other functions that use it.

For example, **isSameRoute(a, b)** (from *vue-router/src/util/route.js*) can return true for routes with different query objects (if query objects meet conditions listed above).  

I ran into this bug because sometimes programmatic navigation worked in unexpected ways when using **router.push** with a query object.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values" (#2233)

Issues.Title: Dynamic modules that use Namespaces need a way to check if they are already registered
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When registering a dynamic module, an error can occur in the console warning that some attributes of the modules are duplicates if the namespace has already been registered. Having a way to check if the namespace path is already occupied would allow the code to either, register to a different namespace (ick!), unregister and re-register the existing namespace or avoid registration of the namespace altogether. 

This condition can be easily reproduced by dynamically registering a namespaced module and issuing a hotreload or attempting to register that module more than once to the same path. 

End users would not see errors on hot-load or, if for some reason, the code attempts multiple registrations in the same session.

The only workaround at this point is to check the private member _modulesNamespaceMap. Building a dependency on that private access isn't ideal. I can find no other way to determine if the namespace is already occupied. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
Option A: Provide a boolean method that returns the state of a given namespace:

    this.$store.isNamespaceRegistered("nested/name/space")

Option B: Exit from registerModule and provide a false return code from registerModule when the namespace already exists. 

    if (this.$store.registerModule("existing/namespace", myModule) === false) {
       this.$store.unregisterModule("existing/namespace")
       this.$store.registerModule("existing/namespace", myModule)
    }

I personally like Option A better as it is minimally intrusive on the existing API and gives the developer the means by which to handle the issue with the greatest flexibility.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dynamic modules that use Namespaces need a way to check if they are already registered" (#1300)

Issues.Title: store.registerGetters and store.registerActions
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
To be able to fully code split all application logic across application routes it would be helpful to have a way to dynamically register getters and actions.  Currently registerModule only supports registering namespaced modules with `store.registerModule`.  

For example lets say you have two namespaced modules that you dynamically load into your application: Sandwich and Human.  The two modules shouldn't know anything about each other.  There needs to be some highter level actions and getters that can tie the two together that you can also dynamically load.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
store.registerActions({
  ...newActions
})

store.registerGetters({
  ...newGetters
})
```
These functions would still throw errors if the user tried to register duplicate actions or getters so it would be up the the user to make sure they are not passing in duplicates by checking existing data and making sure their actions and getters are namespaced appropriately.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "store.registerGetters and store.registerActions" (#1299)

Issues.Title: Option to namespace a module but not have it localized
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
The `namespaced:true` module feature has two main purposes: 

1. it automatically namespaces your modules API ( e.g store.getters['namespace/myGetter']). 
2. it localizes dispatch, commit, getters, and state. 

I'd like is to have an option when defining a module that does 1. but does not do 2. as mentioned above. I understand that there are currently two ways to achieve what I want in user land but neither of them are ideal.

1. Define modules that are `namespaced` that have actions and getters that only reference rootGetters, rootState and dispatch to root. I've never like using the root features. Seems like it throws encapsulation out of the door.
2. Define modules that are not `namespaced` and manually namespace modules yourself. This is currently what I'm doing.

### What does the proposed API look like?

String `namespace` - Setting `namespace` would namespace all actions, getters, and mutations with that value. A "." separator to be able to distinguish between a namespaced module that is localized ("/") and not localized ("."). A module with this setting should never have state as it's only purpose is to group together other modules actions, getters, and mutations to do higher order operations.

Some validations worth calling out.
- if the namespace option was set, validate that there is no state defined. 

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Syntactic sugar for commiting mutations
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Committing mutations has a very strange syntax, which really stands out negatively, compared to the otherwise very elegant APIs found in the Vue/Vuex ecosystem:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

The docs mention that this is to emphasize that a commit is not a direct call to the mutation. I don't think this line of reasoning holds in the Vue/Vuex world. In almost all other aspects of Vue/Vuex, the API looks straight forward (e.g. just getting and setting properties), but under the hood a lot of additional logic runs (dependency tracking, etc.). So there is really no need to make committing mutations more cumbersome than they need to be.

In addition to making the code harder to read, this leads to additional rules about argument passing.

Moreover, it is very hard to spot typos in the mutation name early on, as the mutation name is just a string - let alone checking that the call to `commit()` received the correct arguments according to the mutation function. These types of errors should be easy to spot at compile time, but with the current syntax, these are all pushed into runtime.

Finally, this cumbersome syntax might be (correctly) perceived as boilerplate, especially to beginners. Hence, replacing the commit syntax with a more straight forward syntax might improve the adoption of Vuex.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Instead of:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

one should be allowed to write:

    this.$store.someMutation(args...)

Moreover, it would be great if looking at `this.$store` in the developer console all available mutation methods are shown. That is, the methods should be real properties of this.$store, collected once at program start.

Under the hood, of course, these methods might all call some central commit() function.

Alternative syntax: The above syntax might introduce some name collisions. For example, someone might name one of their mutations "state", for whatever reason, making "this.$store.state" ambiguous. For the sake of simplicity, these names should just be forbidden as mutation names. But if this is not an option for whatever reason, an intermediate object might do the trick as well. This would be less beautiful, but still better than what we have today:

    this.$store.commit.someMutation(args...)

or shorter:

    this.$store.c.someMutation(args...)

As an additional proposal, the old `this.$store.commit()` syntax should be marked deprecated.  And removed in future Vuex versions. This generic call is not needed. Any generic commit call might as well be formulated as `this.$store[mutationName](args...)`, which is still easy to understand and even shorter than `this.$store.commit(mutationName, args...)`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Many Google links returning 404s after conversion
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://vuex.vuejs.org/modules.html](https://vuex.vuejs.org/modules.html)

### Steps to reproduce
Try to visit any of the old URLs, or search Google for vuex topics and try to click through to the guide.  You will get 404s.

### What is expected?
301 redirects are in place so that users attempting to get help get to the right place.

### What is actually happening?
After the conversion to Vuepress it looks like the URL format changed from `vuex.vuejs.org/**.html` to `vuex.vuejs.org/guide/**.html`.  Google has not updated their listings, and many Stackoverflow posts will never update theirs.  As is, many users trying to get help will get frustrated and may give up altogether.

This can be solved quite easily by installing some 301 redirects on the server.

Issues.Title: [docs] incompatible with vuepress
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/Jinjiang/vuex/tree/vuepress](https://github.com/Jinjiang/vuex/tree/vuepress)

### Steps to reproduce
npm run docs

### What is expected?
Just try vuepress to dev/build docs

preview: https://5b01b3bb3672df726f83886e--objective-stonebraker-ca8353.netlify.com

### What is actually happening?
There always be some errors, until I changed some dev deps:

1. remove `rollup-plugin-buble`
2. remove (or upgrade v3 -> v4) `webpack`

by https://github.com/Jinjiang/vuex/commit/b74690d08cb43bff4eaa2031553e004922d802e2

But if I changed them, it failed with other npm scripts.

---
vuepress error branch:
[https://github.com/Jinjiang/vuex/tree/test](https://github.com/Jinjiang/vuex/tree/test)

vuepress error message:

```bash
> vuepress dev docs

Extracting site metadata...TypeError: Cannot destructure property `createHash` of 'undefined' or 'null'.
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/xxxxxxxx/vuex/node_modules/mini-css-extract-plugin/dist/index.js:26:44)
    at Module._compile (module.js:641:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:652:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:560:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:503:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:495:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:585:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:11:18)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/xxxxxxxx/vuex/node_modules/mini-css-extract-plugin/dist/cjs.js:3:18)
    at Module._compile (module.js:641:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:652:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:560:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:503:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:495:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:585:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:11:18)
```

I guess this should be considered as a bug of vuepress or we can do something in Vuex repo to walk around.

Thanks.
